item.title: Top Iranian military commander killed in Israeli airstrike on a consulate building, Tehran says
item.description: Israeli forces withdraw from Gaza's main hospital; Netanyahu faces mass protests

media:content.media:credit: Syrian state news agency via AP
media:content.media:text: Image: People gather near a destroyed building struck by Israeli jets in Damascus, Syria, on April 1, 2024.
media:content.media:description: People gather near a destroyed building struck by Israeli jets in Damascus, Syria, on April 1, 2024.

item.title: The world's oldest royal family dips a toe into social media's perilous waters to win young hearts
item.dc:creator: Mithil Aggarwal and Arata Yamamoto and The Associated Press
item.description: Japan's royal family joined social media on Monday, launching an Instagram account in a bid to appeal to the country's youth with photos of Emperor Naruhito and family.

media:content.media:text: Japan's Princess Aiko Greets Media Upon Her Coming-of-age
media:content.media:description: Japan's Princess Aiko greets the press on the occasion of her coming-of-age at the Imperial Palace in Tokyo in 2021.

media:content.media:text: Japan’s Imperial Family made an Instagram debut on Monday, with images of Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako capturing moments of their official duties, an effort to shake off their cloistered image and reach out to the younger generations.
media:content.media:description: The Instagram page of Japan's Imperial Household, displayed on a cellphone in Tokyo on Monday.

media:content.media:text: Japanese Emperor Naruhito and Royal Family greet public on Emperor's 64th birthday celebrations
media:content.media:description: Emperor Naruhito and his family largely rely on older generations for support after the abdication of his popular father.

item.title: Ex-Taiwanese President Ma visits China to help build social and cultural links
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Former Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou is visiting China to help build social and cultural links on a trip that might include a meeting with Chinese leader Xi Jinping despite heightened tensions.

media:content.media:text: Ma Ying-jeou in Singapore on Oct. 5, 2023.
media:content.media:description: Ma Ying-jeou in 2023.

item.title: GOP Rep. Tim Walberg suggests Gaza should be handled 'like Nagasaki and Hiroshima'
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Cohen and Emma Li and Marin Scott
item.description: Rep. Tim Walberg, R-Mich., said this week that the conflict in Gaza should be over quickly "like Nagasaki and Hiroshima."

media:content.media:text: Rep. Tim Walberg
media:content.media:description: Rep. Tim Walberg, R-Mich., during the House Republicans' news conference at the Capitol on Dec. 6, 2023.

item.title: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu recovering after hernia surgery, hospital says
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press and Yarden Segev
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is recovering after undergoing hernia surgery Sunday, which was successful, a hospital spokesperson said.

media:content.media:text: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu
media:content.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu addresses the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, in Jerusalem, on Feb. 18, 2024.

item.title: An Israeli airstrike hits a Gaza hospital tent camp, killing 2 Palestinians and hurting journalists
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: An Israeli airstrike hit a tent camp in the courtyard of a crowded hospital in central Gaza on Sunday, killing two Palestinians and wounding another 15, including journalists working nearby.

media:content.media:text: Palestinians carry a wounded person following an Israeli airstrike
media:content.media:description: Palestinians carry a wounded person following an Israeli airstrike near the Al Aqsa hospital in Deir al Balah, Gaza, on Sunday.

item.title: She secretly educated herself to escape Afghanistan. Now, she's working to help women still there
item.dc:creator: Maya Eaglin
item.description: Sola Mahfouz stopped going to school in 2007 when she was an 11-year-old living in Afghanistan.

media:content.media:text: A portrait of Sola Mahfouz

item.title: Meet the families who've taken children as young as 2 to Everest Base Camp
item.dc:creator: Aria Bendix
item.description: A handful of families have taken children as young as 2 years old to Mount Everest Base Camp in recent years. Three of them describe the experience.

media:content.media:text: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

media:content.media:text: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, last year when Arishka was just 6 years old.
media:content.media:description: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, to Everest Base Camp last year at 6 years old.

item.title: Looking for leads, not love: Job seekers in China turn Tinder into a networking tool
item.dc:creator: Larissa Gao and Helen Chen
item.description: Young people in China facing an increasingly tough labor market are turning to an unlikely place for help in their job searches: Tinder.

media:content.media:text: Photo Illustration: A man's Tinder profile reads "Looking for Full-tim employment"
media:content.media:description: Some young people in China see Tinder as a way to find potential job leads.

media:content.media:text: China Youth Unemployment
media:content.media:description: University students at a job fair in Wuhan, China, in March.

item.title: How the Israel-Hamas conflict has spread beyond the Mideast
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith and JoElla Carman and Jiachuan Wu
item.description: Four months into the war, fighting has spread from Gaza to Pakistan.

item.title: Anti-government protests erupt across Jerusalem
item.description: Protests against Benjamin Netanyahu’s government erupted in Jerusalem as the prime minister’s cabinet has faced widespread criticism over Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel. Clashes also occurred in the Mea Shearim neighborhood over ultra-Orthodox Jews being allowed exemption from military service.

media:content.media:title: Anti-government protests erupt across Jerusalem
media:content.media:description: Protests against Benjamin Netanyahu’s government erupted in Jerusalem as the prime minister’s cabinet has faced widespread criticism over Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel. Clashes also occurred in the Mea Shearim neighborhood over ultra-Orthodox Jews being allowed exemption from military service.

item.title: Video shows the scale of destruction at Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital after Israeli withdrawal
item.description: Wide-scale destruction was seen at Gaza's Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City following the withdrawal of Israeli forces after a two-week operation during which they killed Palestinian gunmen and seized weaponry and intelligence documents.

media:content.media:title: Video shows the scale of destruction at Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital after Israeli withdrawal
media:content.media:description: Wide-scale destruction was seen at Gaza's Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City following the withdrawal of Israeli forces after a two-week operation during which they killed Palestinian gunmen and seized weaponry and intelligence documents.

item.title: Palestinian Christians attend Easter Mass in Gaza City
item.description: Video shot by NBC News showed dozens of Palestinian Christians gathered at the Holy Family Church in Gaza City to celebrate Easter Sunday amid the ongoing Israel-Hamas war. The church has become a sanctuary for displaced Gazans.

media:content.media:title: Palestinian Christians attend Easter Mass in Gaza City
media:content.media:description: Video shot by NBC News showed dozens of Palestinian Christians gathered at the Holy Family Church in Gaza City to celebrate Easter Sunday amid the ongoing Israel-Hamas war. The church has become a sanctuary for displaced Gazans.

item.title: Christians worldwide celebrate Easter, with the Pope and King Charles leading festivities
item.description: As Christians celebrate Easter, all eyes were on those leading festivities. Pope Francis sounded hoarse but firm during his Easter sermon amid mounting health concerns. King Charles conducted his first major public engagement since announcing his cancer diagnosis during the annual Windsor service, with Princess Kate notably absent. From war-torn lands to 5th Avenue, the holiday’s message of hope persisted. NBC News’ Marissa Parra reports.

media:content.media:title: Christians worldwide celebrate Easter, with the Pope and King Charles leading festivities
media:content.media:description: As Christians celebrate Easter, all eyes were on those leading festivities. Pope Francis sounded hoarse but firm during his Easter sermon amid mounting health concerns. King Charles conducted his first major public engagement since announcing his cancer diagnosis during the annual Windsor service, with Princess Kate notably absent. From war-torn lands to 5th Avenue, the holiday’s message of hope persisted. NBC News’ Marissa Parra reports.

item.title: A Brazilian rising political star's killing was a mystery until an explosive federal report
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Explosive revelations in a 500-page Federal Police report allege ties between federal state civil police chief Rivaldo Barbosa and organized crime in the killing of Councilwoman Marielle Franco, a rising political star and Black LGBTQ woman.

media:content.media:text: People carry posters with images of slain Brazilian councilwoman Marielle Franco
media:content.media:description: People carry posters with images of slain Brazilian councilwoman Marielle Franco during a demonstration against racism, in Lisbon, Portugal, on Feb. 24.

media:content.media:text: Then-Rio de Janeiro Councilwoman Marielle Franco smiles for a photo
media:content.media:description: Then-Rio de Janeiro Councilwoman Marielle Franco in Cinelandia square in Brazil in 2018.

media:content.media:text: Rivaldo Barbosa is escorted by a federal police officer
media:content.media:description: Then-head of the Rio Civil Police, Rivaldo Barbosa, is escorted by a federal police officer upon arrival at the Federal Police headquarters in Rio de Janeiro on March 24.

item.title: Turkey's resurgent opposition thumps Erdogan in pivotal local elections
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Turkish President Reccep Tayyip Erdogan vowed on Monday to correct any mistakes that led to his party’s defeat in local elections where the opposition capitalized on economic woes and alienated Islamist voters, casting uncertainty over his reform plans.

media:content.media:text: Turkey’s resurgent opposition thumps Erdogan in pivotal local elections
media:content.media:description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan before casting his ballot in Istanbul on March 31, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Turkey's main opposition party retained its control over key cities and made huge gains elsewhere in Sunday's local elections, preliminary results showed, in a major upset to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who had set his sights on retaking control of those urban areas. (AP Photo/Khalil Hamra)
media:content.media:description: Republican People's Party supporters gather to celebrate outside City Hall in Istanbul Sunday night.

item.title: South Korea's president vows not to back down in the face of doctors' strike
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: South Korea’s president vowed not to back down in the face of protests by doctors seeking to derail his plan to drastically increase medical school admissions.

media:content.media:text: People watch a TV screen showing the live broadcast of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol’s addressing the nation at the Seoul Railway Station in Seoul, South Korea, Monday, April 1, 2024.
media:content.media:description: In a nationally televised address, President Yoon Suk Yeol said an increase in medical school admissions was needed to address a shortage of physicians.

media:content.media:text: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol on April 1, slammed the "cartel" of medics who oppose sector reforms, saying the government would not back down on plans that have triggered a month-long doctors strike.
media:content.media:description: A medical worker outside an emergency room in Seoul, South Korea, on Monday.

item.title: Shadowy Russian actors spread Princess Kate conspiracies, analysis finds
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith
item.description: Social media accounts linked to a prominent Russian disinformation campaign capitalized on conspiracy theories about Kate, Princess of Wales, an analysis found.

media:content.media:text: Princess Kate social media
media:content.media:description: Princess Kate announcing her cancer diagnosis, viewed via Instagram last week.

item.title: Pope Francis delivers Easter Sunday address amid concerns for his frail health
item.dc:creator: Claudio Lavanga and Yuliya Talmazan and Reuters
item.description: Pope Francis delivers Easter Sunday address, amid concerns for his health, and an end to the wars in Gaza and Ukraine

media:content.media:text: Pope Francis waves from the central loggia of St. Peter's basilica
media:content.media:description: Pope Francis at St. Peter's basilica during the Easter 'Urbi et Orbi' message and blessing to the City and the World as part of the Holy Week celebrations, in the Vatican, on March 31, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Pope Francis waves from the central loggia of St. Peter's basilica
media:content.media:description: Pope Francis waves from the central loggia of St. Peter's basilica during the Urbi et Orbi message and blessing on Easter Sunday.

media:content.media:text: Image:
media:content.media:description: Pope Francis greets the faithful from atop his popemobile after celebrating Easter Mass in St. Peter's Square at the Vatican.

media:content.media:text: Image:
media:content.media:description: Pope Francis arrives in a wheelchair in St. Peter's Square at the Vatican for Easter Sunday Mass.

item.title: Ships with a second round of aid for Gaza have departed Cyprus as concerns about hunger soar
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A three-ship convoy left a port in Cyprus on Saturday with 400 tons of food and other supplies for Gaza as concerns about hunger in the territory soar.

media:content.media:text: Displaced Palestinians gather to collect food
media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians gather to collect food in Rafah on March 11.

media:content.media:text: Cargo ships.
media:content.media:description: Cargo ships loaded with aid destined for Gaza prepare to set sail outside the Cypriot port of Larnaca on Saturday.

media:content.media:text: Palestinian women arrange kitchen utensils to dry atop a destroyed car at a makeshift camp for displaced people.
media:content.media:description: Palestinian women arrange kitchen utensils to dry atop a destroyed car at a makeshift camp for displaced people in Rafah on Saturday.

media:content.media:text: A displaced Palestinian girl washes kitchen utensils on the beach as fishermen sail in a boat.
media:content.media:description: A displaced Palestinian girl washes kitchen utensils on the beach as fishermen sail in a boat in Rafah on Saturday.

item.title: Zelenskyy fires more aides in a reshuffle as Russia launches drones and missiles across Ukraine
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy dismissed a longtime aide and several advisers on Saturday in a continuing reshuffle while Russia unleashed fresh attacks overnight.

media:content.media:text: Image:
media:content.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier rests in a trench on the front line in the Donetsk region of Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: Three U.N. observers and a translator wounded in south Lebanon, peacekeeping mission says
item.dc:creator: Reuters and Aurora Almendral
item.description: An strike on Saturday hit a vehicle carrying United Nations technical observers outside the southern Lebanese border town of Rmeish, wounding several observers, two security sources told Reuters, who attriubted the strike to Israel.

item.title: Art world descends on Hong Kong as security laws spur censorship fears
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett
item.description: A new national security law has deepened fears about self-censorship in the arts in Hong Kong, one of the world’s biggest art markets.

media:content.media:text: Art Basel Hong Kong 2024
media:content.media:description: An installation at the Asia edition of Art Basel in Hong Kong on Thursday.

media:content.media:text: "Pillar Of Shame" Statue Faces Threats Of Removal At HK University
media:content.media:description: A sculpture memorializing the victims of the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown was removed from the University of Hong Kong campus in 2021.

media:content.media:text: Lawmakers vote for Article 23 in the chamber of the Legislative Council
media:content.media:description: A local national security law was unanimously approved by Hong Kong lawmakers on March 19.

media:content.media:text: Hong Kong Art Basel
media:content.media:description: A visitor taking photos of works by British artist Mr Doodle at Art Basel on Wednesday.

item.title: A man suspected of holding 4 hostages for hours in a Dutch nightclub has been arrested
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Heavily armed police cordoned off part of a Dutch town on Saturday, saying that multiple people were being held hostage, and have evacuated nearby homes.

media:content.media:text: Heavily armed police have cordoned off part of a Dutch town and say that multiple people are being held hostage in a building there.
media:content.media:description: Heavily armed police have cordoned off part of a Dutch town and say that multiple people are being held hostage in a building there.

item.title: U.S. welcomes a new Palestinian government after making repeated calls for political reform
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: The United States has welcomed the formation of a new Palestinian autonomy government, signaling it is accepting the revised Cabinet lineup as a step toward Palestinian political reform.

media:content.media:text: Image: Mahmoud Abbas
media:content.media:description: In a file photo, Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas speaks at the Arab League headquarters in Cairo in 2023.
